brief.brief: Rapid Application Development (RAD) enables you to build reliable applications quickly and easily.

detail.detail: After designing an application, build it with Rapid Application Development (RAD).
1. Set up all tables and forms using Forms Designer and the Database Dictionary utility.
2. Set up the Application Encyclopedia record. This operation automatically builds a default parameter form for the application. You can modify the parameter form later, if necessary.

Specify the name of the application, the application's title, and brief comments that define the application's function. The Application Encyclopedia creates the parameter form and displays the Encyclopedia record after you press F1 or click Create Application.
3. Modify the parameter from the Encyclopedia record, press F2 or click Edit Application and then press Enter.
Service Manager displays the parameter form with the application and label fields filled in.
- Fill in the comments field, and the normal and error fields.
- Type "$normal" in the field called normal.
- Type "$error" in the field called error.
- Type parameter names (beginning with dollar signs ($)) in all the parameter fields if you have added any, and press Enter.
4. Put in the command panels.
- Indicate the name of the next command panel in the Application field and press F 4 or click Application.
- Fill in the command panel.
Label is a required field.
- Press Enter.
Rapid Application Development (RAD) fills in the label from the previous panel, provided it is not a duplicate of an existing label within the application and it is not a variable name.
- Add the rest of the panels.
When finished, press F5 or click Compile.
If there are obvious errors, Service Manager displays error messages. Correct these errors and recompile.
5. Test the application.
- From the Encyclopedia record, press F9 or click Test Application.
- Fill in the parameter names and values to pass the application (if any) and then run it by pressing Enter.
- When completed, press F 3 or click End to return to the Application Encyclopedia.

Note: You can only enter character-valued parameters when using F9 for testing. To test applications with non-character-valued parameters, build a test application that calls the new application using the application's parameter form.
